basic.title: MongoDB listens on a port different to default one
basic.caption: Using the default MongoDB port makes it too easy for potential attackers to locate and target your server.
messages: Your server is listening on default port 27017.
Your server is listening in a non-obvious port. Well done.
basic.call2action: Please read [[this guide on how to change the listening port]].

basic.title: Server only accepts connections from whitelisted hosts / networks
basic.caption: Best practice is to only listen to incoming connections whose originating IP belongs to the applications or systems that are intended to use the database. This protects your server from denial-of-service attacks and some other vulnerabilities that may be present on other services running on the same device.
messages: Your server does accept connections from unauthorized hosts or it could not be found at all. No more tests will be run.
Your server does not accept connections from unauthorized hosts. Well done.
basic.call2action: Please read [[this guide on how to create whitelists and block unauthorized hosts]].

basic.title: MongoDB HTTP status interface is not accessible on port 28017
basic.caption: HTTP status interface should be disabled in production environments to prevent potential data exposure and vulnerability to attackers.
messages: HTTP status interface is enabled.
HTTP status interface is disabled. Well done.
basic.call2action: Please [[read this guide on how to disable MongoDB HTTP status interface]].

basic.title: MongoDB is not exposing its version number
basic.caption: Publicly exposing the version number makes it too easy for potential attackers to immediately exploit known vulnerabilities.
messages: MongoDB version number is exposed. This could be solved by putting a reverse proxy between MongoDB and the Internet.
MongoDB is hiding its version number. Well done.

basic.title: MongoDB version is newer than 2.4
basic.caption: MongoDB versions equal and prior to 2.4 amass an alarming number of security issues that make them specially vulnerable to injection and denial of service attacks.
messages: You are running MongoDB version
, which is highly vulnerable.
You are running MongoDB version
. Well done.
basic.call2action: Please read [[this guide on how to upgrade to MongoDB's latest stable version]] and consider upgrading as soon as possible.

basic.title: TLS/SSL encryption is available
basic.caption: TLS/SSL in-flight encryption authenticates and encrypts connections between your MongoDB server and apps to avoid eavesdropping, tampering and “man in the middle” attacks.
messages: TLS/SSL encryption is NOT available and your connections are unprotected from eavesdropping.
TLS/SSL encryption is available. The next test will check whether it is enabled.
basic.call2action: Please read [[this guide on how to add TLS/SSL support to MongoDB]].

basic.title: TLS/SSL encryption is enabled
basic.caption: Enable TLS/SSL in-flight encryption to authenticate and encrypt connections between your MongoDB server and apps to avoid eavesdropping, tampering and “man in the middle” attacks.
messages: TLS/SSL encryption is NOT enabled and your connections are unprotected from eavesdropping.
TLS/SSL encryption is enabled. Well done.
basic.call2action: Please read [[this guide on how to enable TLS/SSL encryption on MongoDB]].

basic.title: TLS/SSL certificate is valid
basic.caption: Your production MongoDB deployments should always use valid certificates generated by a certificate authority. Only certificates signed by a trusted certificate authority will allow MongoDB drivers to verify the server’s identity.
messages: The server's TLS/SSL certificate is not signed by a trusted certification authority.
Your TLS/SSL certificate is valid and your connections are safe from eavesdropping. Well done.
basic.call2action: Please read [[this guide on how to configure valid TLS/SSL encryption on MongoDB]].

basic.title: authentication is enabled
basic.caption: Authentication requires that all clients provide valid credentials before they can connect to the server. All production servers MUST use authentication.
messages: Authentication is NOT enabled. You are inviting everyone out there to enter your databases, seize everything and potentially ransom you for your data.
Authentication is enabled. Well done.
basic.call2action: Please read [[this guide on how to enable authentication on MongoDB]].

advanced.title: authentication credentials are valid
advanced.caption: To continue running the tests, the provided credentials must be valid.
messages: Invalid authentication credentials. Can not continue with the tests. Please provide valid credentials.
Provided authentication credentials are valid. Testing will continue.

advanced.title: SCRAM-SHA-1 authentication method is enabled
advanced.caption: SCRAM-SHA-1 is more secure than the previously-used MONGODB-CR authentication method, given that it provides a tunable work factor, per-user random salts, stronger hashes (SHA-1 rather than MD5), and bidirectional authentication.
messages: SCRAM-SHA-1 is NOT enabled.
SCRAM-SHA-1 is enabled and being used. Well done.
advanced.call2action: Please read [[this guide on how to use SCRAM-SHA1 as the default authentication method in MongoDB]].

advanced.title: server-side Javascript is forbidden
advanced.caption: Running Javascript inside queries makes MongoDB powerful but also vulnerable to injection and denial-of-service attacks. Javascript should be always disabled unless it is strictly needed by your application.
messages: Usage of Javascript IS allowed inside queries, which is potentially harmful.
Usage of Javascript is not allowed inside queries. Well done.
advanced.call2action: Please read [[this guide on how to disable server-side Javascript]].

advanced.title: roles granted to the provided user only permit CRUD operations
advanced.caption: Your user should only be allowed to perform CRUD (Create, Replace, Update and Delete) operations. Granting database administration roles such as “dbAdmin”, “dbOwner” or “userAdmin” is a huge risk for data integrity.
messages: The permissions contained in your user's role set
are way too high.
The permissions contained in your user's role set
are sensible. Well done.
advanced.call2action: Please read [[this guide on roles and permissions best practices]].
